turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: The unhappy tale of a virginal laundry lass, the darling of the lower wards, where they entomb the criminally insane.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Is it awfully violent?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Most assuredly.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Is it terribly erotic?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Fiendishly so.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: A kiss for each page.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Must I administer them directly, or might I blow them?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: The price, my coquette, is every bit as firm as I am...

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Oh, you. You talk same as you write.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: It's a long story, this one.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: The climax comes at a higher cost; you must sit on my lap.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: You demand a lot from your readers, you do.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: The story's thrilling conclusion comes at a premium.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: What's that then?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: What have they done to you now?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Tortures so arcane, so medieval, even I haven't the words to describe them. If you've an ounce of pity in your heart, you'll throw caution aside, and unlock my door...

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: My newest book begins at my right cuff, continues across my back, and completes itself at the base of my left shoe...

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I don't believe it!

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: They've taken your clothes?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: They decreed me a savage, and now they have made me one.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Surely you've seen a man naked.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: It's only been described to me. In your books.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: I must say, in your novels you stoke the most unrealistic expectations.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: You're far crueler than I, my sweet.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: The Abbe's sending me away. He fears for me here, what with the likes of you --

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Don't be fooled, Madeleine! He fears for himself. He's like a man starving, and you -- ha! -- you're like a pork chop dolloped with heavy cream --

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: He's a man of God; he's true to his vows.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: First and foremost, he's a MAN. You remind him of that fact, and he resents you for it.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: It needn't be; not if you've another story.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: How do you propose I write it? With dust, upon the air?

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: You could whisper it through the walls of your cell.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Yes; that's it! A final volley from us both!

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Go on, child.

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: Tomorrow night, whisper a new tale to your neighbor, Cleante. He'll whisper it to his neighbor Dauphin, who'll whisper it to his neighbor Franval --

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: -- who'll whisper it to Bouchon --

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: -- whose cell lies next to the linen cabinet! There, armed with a quill of my own, I'll commit it to paper!

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Yes! You shall. Of course you shall --

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: A tale more horrible than all the rest combined!

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Something to make the angels weep, and the Saints to gasp for air...

turns.speaker: MADELEINE
turns.text: ...yes, I've got that bit...

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: "What shall I ready?" asked Fanchon. "My mouth, my ass or my succulent oyster?"

turns.speaker: MONSIEUR PROUIX
turns.text: "...your wife."

turns.speaker: SIMONE
turns.text: Tell him I'm no fool. A prison's still a prison, even with Chinese silk and chandeliers.

turns.speaker: MONSIEUR PROUIX
turns.text: "By the time you read this, we'll be long gone; bound for England or points beyond..."

turns.speaker: SIMONE
turns.text: Tell him -- if he uncovers our whereabouts -- you'll slit your wrists with a razor, and I'll plunge a hat- pin through my heart.

turns.speaker: MONSIEUR PROUIX
turns.text: You'd do that, rather than forsake our love?

turns.speaker: SIMONE
turns.text: No. But tell him I would.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: It is customary to write first, and request an appointment --

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: Desperation has driven me past etiquette, all the way to frenzy.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: My schedule is not subject to the whims of lunatics.

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: I beg to differ, Doctor. You work in a madhouse. Your every waking moment is governed by the insane.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: I pray you: be succinct.

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: You're new to Charenton, yes? Perhaps you're not yet familiar with my husband, and his unusual case.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: With all due respect, Madame, all France is familiar with your husband.  Grant us a moment alone, won't you, Monsieur Prouix?

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: I assume you've come to plead for clemency on your husband's behalf.

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: Oh you do, do you? It is my dearest hope, Doctor, that he remain entombed forever, and that when at last he perishes in the dank bowels of your institution, he be left as carrion for the rodents and the worms.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: You're aware, are you not, that it costs a great deal to house your husband at Charenton...

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: I pay his stipend every month, far more dutifully than I should.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: That barely covers the cost of his room. There's nary a penny left over for appropriate treatments. Opiates to quell his temper. Restraints to chasten him when he misbehaves.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Perhaps if you were to buttress your entreaties with the means to oblige them...

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: I am not a wealthy woman.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: But you've a pension, haven't you, from the sale of his books?

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: It's tainted money, Doctor.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: What a beautiful thought, Marquise.

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: What thought is that?

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: That ill-gotten funds, borne of his degeneracy, might now effect his salvation.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: If you're truly determined to step out of the shadow of your husband's celebrity --

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: Oh, but I am!

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: -- words alone are insufficient.

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: It's beyond perversity. That honor should carry a price tag...

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: Don't toy with me, Doctor.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Now is the time to secure your epitaph. The benevolent Marquise, Charenton's most revered philanthropist... or Satan's Bride.

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: I am eternally in your debt.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: And I in yours.

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: Doctor... Can I impart to you his cruelest trick?

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: Once... long ago... in the folly of youth... he made me love him.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Good God, Marquise --

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: I'm on the brink of bankruptcy; my husband's resources are all but exhausted. And to what end, I ask you?

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: This is neither the time nor the place --

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: If only you'd remained true to our contract! Opiates, for his nerves! Restraints! The man warrants a bed of nails --

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: I can say, with the utmost sincerity, that every franc you've given me has been put to sterling use.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: You've no right to assault me in this fashion; I'll call for my footman. I'll have you removed --

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: Am I a cursed woman, Doctor? Must I be betrayed by every man I meet --

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: Public scorn carries a terrible sting. Trust me. I'm a woman who knows.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: It's libelous; you wouldn't dare.

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: And why not? My fortune, siphoned away. My reputation, past repair. I've nothing left to lose.  Silence my husband, or you'll come to know an infamy to rival his own.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Hm? Tell me. What other treats?

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: ....shame on you, truly...

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: For fuck's sake, woman! BONBONS? I'm to sit here, gorging myself on useless trifles, sucking down your little sweetmeats, when what I truly need -- what I truly require -- are a few quill pens? Perhaps a pot of ink?

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: Forgive me, I beg you --

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: How was I to know, my darling?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: How was I to tell you? By writing a letter? WITH WHAT, MY ASININE BRIDE?

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: I beg you, Donatien... as your wife... your only ally... you must stop making such a monstrous spectacle of yourself.

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: You've come to lecture me?

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: To flaunt your deviance in public? Upon a stage?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: They've put you up to this, haven't they?

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: You ought to court the Doctor's favor, not his contempt.

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: Everywhere I go, they point and whisper! At the opera, they hiss at me when I take my box. When I went to church... the priest refused to even hear my confession; he said I was already damned! Why must I suffer for your sins?

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: It's the way of all martyrs, isn't it?

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: Give me back my anonymity, that's all I ask! Let me be invisible again!

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: Tell me; have you done anything to secure my release? NO! Have you petitioned the court? NEVER! Sought audience with the Emperor --

turns.speaker: RENEE PELAGIE
turns.text: He refuses to be seen in my company! He blanches at the mention of your name --

turns.speaker: THE MARQUIS
turns.text: It's a convenience, isn't it, having your husband locked away! You no longer have to hold your tongue, or hoist your skirts! Or crack your mouth, so I can put it to its one pleasurable use! YOU'RE NOT MY WIFE, NO! YOU'RE ONE AMONG MY MANY JAILERS, AREN'T YOU?

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Leave at once --

turns.speaker: SIMONE
turns.text: But it's just begun --

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Do as I say.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: Doesn't that please you?

turns.speaker: SIMONE
turns.text: Very much.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: I'd prefer to have our brandy in the salon. There we can sit... side-by- side... before the fire.

turns.speaker: SIMONE
turns.text: I'd rather read, thank-you.

turns.speaker: ROYER-COLLARD
turns.text: You prefer a book to your husband's company?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Ever met Walter Winchell?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: No, when I was but a tender lad--

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: Last week would this be?

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: So you ever gonna do a picture?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Not you too

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: It's gonna be fine, Orson. You're gonna do great.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I wonder sometimes.

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: You're just scared.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Am I?

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: Of being found out. Of not being a genius

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Oh, but haven't you heard? I'm the Boy Wonder. I've been a genius since the moment I was born.

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: We've known each other too long, Orson. Sling the bullshit elsewhere.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Carole, you wound me! As if I could hope to pacify you with evasions of--

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: Don't insult me with your cute press quotes Save it for Louella.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: That poor woman.

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: She knew what she was signing on for After all, she took the money.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: And we would hear them scuttling around at night with their little red eyes and little yellow t-t- teeth and I'm just imagining plague lice jumpin' all over the damn place So we set t-t-traps everywhere. And every morning we would find the t-t-traps sprung but no mice!

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: Houdini mice.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: God, these parties are the worst

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: You need to get outta here, Rapunzel

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: That's why he has the parties, he says it's like bringing the world to me.

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: Why don't you come down to LA? Stay with us for a while.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: With about twenty of his spies on my tail. No thanks.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: It's not so bad here. After all, what girl doesn't want to live in a castle?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Mr. Welles certainly is a caution

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: Yeah, Orson's a real piece of work. But deep down, he's a good kid. Real deep down.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: And attractive in a hammy sort of way.

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: Mm.

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: Listen, you come down and stay with us for a few days. Just tell the old man that--

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I can't

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: Sure you can, just--

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: He needs me here.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: When I met him I was just 20. And he was 55. I saw the gold ring and just grabbed on. And he was going to make me a star.

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: And he did.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I did my best but, well, you know me

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: Sure

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Thing that bothers me now, though, looking back is that I really think I could have been something ... special.

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: Thinking like that is only gonna drive you nuts You were a great star and you had a good run. That oughta be enough.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Yeah. But all of a sudden it's not

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: You know this CITIZEN KANE picture? About Pops and everything?

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: Uh-huh

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: The character that's supposed to be me, Susan Alexander--

turns.speaker: CAROLE LOMBARD
turns.text: Marion, everyone knows you're not like that--

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: But I am That's the killer, honey.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Who are you, sir?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: My name is Orson Welles

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: The actor

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: And director.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: I see. And you are in California for what reason?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: To make pictures.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Well, I wish you luck. It is a treacherous business.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: So I've been told.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: In Hollywood the fiercest bulls are the most brutally killed.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I'll remember that.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: I wonder. Do you have any idea what you have done?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Do you?

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Intimately. For every sin you have placed on my head I could give you a hundred others. I have been swimming in blood my entire life. But I retain a belief, perhaps you will think it old fashioned, undoubtedly you will, but I believe that private lives should not be public property.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Elegant words, sir, when you have made your name and your fortune on slander and innuendo and gossip. In your papers you taught the world how to look under every rock. I learned at the knee of the master.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: So where does that leave us, Mr. Welles? What kind of sad future are we two making? A future where men will do anything to sell their newspapers and their movies? A future where no price is too high for fame and power? When we will all scratch each other to pieces just to be heard?

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Louis

turns.speaker: MAYER
turns.text: Randolph!

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Hope you don't mind my popping in--

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Quite. And this is why I came to visit. Have you heard about this CITIZEN KANE picture?

turns.speaker: MAYER
turns.text: Over at RKO?

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Mm. Not a very good picture I am told.

turns.speaker: MAYER
turns.text: Uh-hub.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Apparently it details the exploits of a publisher like myself. Entirely too much like myself. Do you follow so far?

turns.speaker: MAYER
turns.text: Yeah

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: And maybe we could get Mr. Warner and Mr. Goldwyn and Mr. Cohn and Mr. Selznick to play as well.

turns.speaker: MAYER
turns.text: You know that can't happen.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Oh, why is that?

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Why is that, Louis?

turns.speaker: MAYER
turns.text: Bel Air is restricted.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: See what you can do about this CITIZEN KANE picture, won't you?

turns.speaker: MAYER
turns.text: Yeah

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Goddamn it. I gotta have some kinda life!

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: There's no call for that language-

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: There certainly is I There certainly is! Aw, to hell with you!

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: This is supposed ta be Siam or some such. Some kinda lousy B-B-Balinese temple. This look like a temple to you? I can't see it myself--

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Darling, I talked to Millicent.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: There. That's right.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: She's a Catholic. She says it would put her soul in peril. Divorce is a very serious sin, apparently.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Nuts. She only cares about the money. She thinks I'll make you cut her out of the w-w-w-w...  will.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: The Journal was pretty harsh to Roosevelt today.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: You oughta lay off him -- he is the p-p-president, after all.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: He is a Bolshevik. He will have us at war by the end of the year. I think I'm going to run that wheelchair picture.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Don't

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: How bad is it?

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Nothing for you to worry about, darling

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Pops

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: The S.E.C. has turned down my request for relief on the debts.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: How much?

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: It's not really--

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: How much?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: We're 125 million dollars in debt?

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: How does one get 125 million dollars in debt?

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: One . . . buys things.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Well -- he got us, didn't he? She stands and goes quickly to pour a drink. A forced laugh

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Nailed us, hub? The crazy old man and his whore.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Marion--

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Bought and p-p-paid for. Just like one of his goddamn statues. Well at least in the movie he married her!

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: This picture--

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I am not that woman.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Then you explain it to me?!

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: There's nothing to explain

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: A million dollars a year on art and st-st-statues and there's nothing to explain?!

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: I will not defend my life to you--

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I'm not asking you to defend anything. But we're in a pickle and we gotta talk about it.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: We are in no "pickle" -- as you would euphemistically have it.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: You gotta wake up now. Pops.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: There is nothing to discuss-

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: You don't have any money left, okay?! That's the truth. I don't wanna say it, nobody else will say it, but it's the truth. You spent it all. You can't buy the Tribune in Chicago -- you can't buy ^ g-g- goddamn thing. Now you better face up to it--

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: You are being typically theatrical, Marion. I need the Tribune to--

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: You don't need it! That's the problem you always think you need everything--

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: That -- did you need that? How much did that cost?

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: It's 12th Century. From Deauville -- in France.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I know where Deauville is for C-C-Christ's sake.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: You needn't use that language with me

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Did you need it? Did you need any of it?

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: I wanted it

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: There's a different between want and

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Not for me.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: But why? Just so you can show it all off -- just so everyone can see what a b-b-big man you are?!

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: That's right. You've captured me exactly. Goodnight.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: You will not walk out on me

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: You are repellant when you drink.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Tough shit. We need to t-t-talk about this--

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: You are slovenly and unattractive and I won't  t-t-t-tolerate it.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Fuck you, Mr. Kane.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: I will not have this in my home.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I just want to understand--

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: No, you don't. You want to condemn me, like everyone else. You want to point to the pathetic, old man grown lunatic with his spending -- trapped in his ridiculous

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: castle -- still fighting old battles he will never win with Pulitzer and Roosevelt and Hollywood--

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I don't want you to--

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: There is nothing to understand but this:   I am a man who could have been great, but was not.

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: It's all you. It has the political campaigns and the mining fortune and the war with Pulitzer and the castle. And ... Marion.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: How so?

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: The jigsaw puzzles and the, urn, career -- the man spending a fortune to make her a star -- only it's opera and not movies. And...

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: The drinking.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Thank you for your time

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: Thank you, sir. She begins to leave

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Miss Parsons, I have one additional question for you.

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Why did we not know about this sooner?

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: I pay you a good deal of money to be my eyes and ears in Hollywood, do I not? If you cannot provide this simple service you are of no use to me.

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: Sir, I-

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Please be quiet.

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: He lied to me

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: He looked into my face and told me it wasn't about you.

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: And how do you feel when you are lied to?

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: I want blood

turns.speaker: HEARST
turns.text: Good. Retain that feeling. Let it nourish you from this day forth. It shall nourish us both

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: "Well, if you got drunk to talk to me about Miss Alexander, don't bother. I'm not interested. I've set back the sacred cause of reform, is that it? All right, if that's the way they want it, the people have made their choice. It's obvious the people prefer Jim Gettys to me."

turns.speaker: JOSEPH COTTON
turns.text: "You talk about the people as if you owned them. As though they belonged to you. As long as I can remember, you've talked about--"  Orson, I am so goddamn tired--

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Keep filming.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH COTTON
turns.text: I can't remember the lines!

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Then make them up! You're drunk and you're angry.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: This is the chance you've been waiting for, boy. Tell that son of a bitch just what you think of him!

turns.speaker: JOSEPH COTTON
turns.text: We're not all hopped up on benzedrine, Orson I Some of us humans need sleep!

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: You're not going to get another chance, boy! Look right at the monster and you tell him--

turns.speaker: JOSEPH COTTON
turns.text: "You don't care about anything except you. You just want to persuade people that you

turns.speaker: JOSEPH COTTON
turns.text: love them so much that they ought to love you back. Only you want love on your own terms. "

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: "A toast then, Jedediah, to love on my own terms. Those are the only terms anybody ever knows, his own."

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Tome it's a question of truth and illusion. Don't you get tired of the errant falsity in motion pictures?

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: What we are going to do is shoot life -- in all it's joyous complexity.

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: Now, Orson, you know I'm just dyin' to see your picture and I know it's gonna be boffo, but you're writing about a publisher, right?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: We're using-

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: You're not doin' Hearst, are you?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Good God no! The character is a delicious amalgamation of various press barons--

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: A delicious amalgamation, is it?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: That's right. A symphony of those: vaunted and valued tellers-of-truth. Those heroic minutemen standing sentry on our liberties--

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: Orson, hold on. Look into my eyes. Tell me you are not doing Hearst.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I am not doing Hearst.

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: Schaefer, I gotta see this Welles picture

turns.speaker: SCHAEFER
turns.text: Louella, hello, I was just fixing a drink, would you like--?

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: You drink at 10 am, do you?

turns.speaker: SCHAEFER
turns.text: No -- no -- I mean--

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: I wanna see the picture today

turns.speaker: SCHAEFER
turns.text: That might be a tad difficult because Orson is scoring the picture now and he's very particular about the music--

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: Cut the malarkey, buddy. The boss himself wants me to see the picture today.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFER
turns.text: He personally asked you to?

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: That's right

turns.speaker: SCHAEFER
turns.text: Hearst?

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: Uh-huh

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: That's right, fella, no Hearst paper will run an RKO ad until you agree that CITIZEN KANE will never see the light of day.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFER
turns.text: Louella, please, be reasonable, I understand you have problems with Orson's picture but maybe we can work something out--

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: Nix, sweetie. You shelve it

turns.speaker: SCHAEFER
turns.text: Oh for God's sake, Louella-

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: And Mr. Hearst has authorized me to tell you that you're looking at the most beautiful lawsuit in history if you release this picture. He'll bleed your little studio dry and you can all go on back to New York and do Shakespeare with the Boy Wonder.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFER
turns.text: Can I talk to Hearst?

turns.speaker: LOUELLA
turns.text: You are talking to him.

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: I don't know what you expected with Joseph- fucking-Conrad for Chrissake. I mean this is Hollywood, pal.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: All right! Enough! I've heard this from Schaefer and RKO. I've heard it from everyone--

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: But you keep coming up with the same elitist crap - - HEART OF DARKNESS with a million dollar budget?! - - no one wants to see that.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Nonsense

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: What are movies about, Orson?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Forget it-

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: What are movies about?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Telling stories.

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Showing life

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Who the hell wants to see life?! People are sick to death of life! They want make-believe, pal. Fantasy. They want Tarzan and Jane, not Tristan and Isolde.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Magic

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Butts on seats. That's what movies are about. You got one job in Hollywood -- everyone has the same job, in fact -- putting the butts on the seats. You gotta sell 'em popcorn and Pepsi- cola. It's all about popcorn and Pepsi-cola.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Not for me.

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Then you better get ready to be the youngest never- was in Hollywood history.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: That's better than being the oldest has-been in Hollywood history.

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: You're a laugh-riot, kid.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: So, we've got to come up with our movie. Our biography.

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Right-

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: We find the man and then we dissect him-

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Like a bug.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: But with compassion and insight--

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Christ, we gotta go! The old man doesn't cotton to lateness.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: How about Howard Hughes? We could do Hughes

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: I'm not fucking with Hughes. That shit-kicker would kill us dead, baby. Just like Jean Harlow

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Howard Hughes killed Jean Harlow?

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Sure. Dropped her out of his Lockheed over Utah

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Sigmund Freud?

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Kid, you just got your ass kicked on Joseph Conrad and now you're gonna go to Schaefer and tell him you wanna do the id and the superego? Stop being so goddamn smart.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Manolete?!

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Who the hell's Manolete?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: The great Spanish bullfighter

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: I don't wanna write about no spic.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: No, it's perfect! When in doubt, put on a cape! False noses and faux beards and flowing capes have been the life-blood of the actor's craft since the days of lrving and Booth.  Imagine me in a glittering suit of lights on the dusky Andalusian plains--

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: The man doesn't allow drinking or cigars? This is monstrous.

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: The old man has his own way of doing things

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: He's nothing but a hypocrite. He preaches morality every day in his sordid little papers for everyone else in the world but he lives openly with his mistress.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Look at those hands. Those are the hands of an artist. A modern Caravaggio.

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: No, baby, those are the hands of a killer

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: "In Xanadu did Kubla Khan a stately pleasure dome decree. . . "How big is it, all told? The estate?

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: The whole joint is half the size of Rhode Island.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Jesus

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Yeah, it's the place God would have built, if he'd had the money.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Mank! You scoundrel! What took you so long?!

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Orson, please ... it's too bright

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Here you are, up with the birds for once, you vampire!

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Okay, boy wonder, what?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Listen ... I've got it! It came to me like a thief in the night! Pure inspiration! Total magnificence!

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Oh for Christ's sake-

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I know who we're going to get I The great American biography! A journey into the soul of the beast.

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: This better be good

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Image a man that has shaped his time. A titanic figure of limitless influence. Think about empire. A man with an empire at his feet. A man, like a baron, living in a palace, a glorious palace on a hill, and controlling the permutations of everyone beneath him. Feudal.

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Oh Christ...

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Image the possibilities as this man controls the public perception of the nation through his--

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Oh Christ

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Please don't say this.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Mank-

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Don't whisper it. Don't even think it

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: How long have we spent casting our minds about the world when the answer to our prayers was right here under our noses -- every single day in the newspapers and on the radio -- waiting for us in that ridiculous castle! Waiting for--!

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Orson. Stop. Just stop

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Now remember he's a public figure who sought out that publicity so legally he can't stop us from--

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Listen to you. You child! Men like him don't bother with things like legality. They don't have to. You know why, boy-o?   Power.   Power like you couldn't even begin to imagine.

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Howard Hughes, he would just kill us. Hearst he would kill us and fuck everything we ever loved.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: We're doing Hearst.

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: You may think you know what you're talking about, kid, but believe me, you don't. You're talking about going into a battle you can never win on a battlefield so far above things like movies and Hollywood that Hearst won't even have to glance down when he crushes you. When he flicks you away with one finger. I'm talking about money and influence and evil beyond your capacity to imagine Hell.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: So speaks the court jester.

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Fuck you

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I expected more from you.

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Sorry to disappoint.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: How does it feel, Mank? Going up to the palace and making all the lords and ladies laugh as you tell your little stories and beg for crumbs at the table? How does it feel being the ugly little monkey they keep to amuse themselves--?!

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I remember a man who wrote I He was a brilliant writer who dazzled me time and time again with his wit and insight--

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Don't do this

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Where did he go? He hasn't had a screen credit in four years--

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Don't do this

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: --Because he has been so furiously busy wasting himself. Amusing his keepers. Because he is a sycophant! Because he has been thrown out of every studio in Hollywood and no one will hire him because he's a drunk- -!

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Let me out.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Listen to me-

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Fuck you--

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I am giving you the last chance you will ever have to be yourself again!

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: I don't have it anymore?!

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: When I was a kid I wanted to scorch the world too - - I had all kinda dreams about making great pictures and telling great stories. But all that's finished for me--

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: It doesn't have to be

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: And yeah, sure, Hearst's a great subject. Been keeping notes on him for years for my ...  great American novel. But I can't do it anymore. No studio's gonna hire me and I - -

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: I'll hire you  -- right now-

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: I can't do it. okay?! I drink too much -- I drink all the fucking time and I don't have it anymore. All that is over for me--

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: NOT UNLESS I. TELL YOU IT IS

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: He'll destroy us.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: Then let him. What have we got to lose, you and I?

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: So, who is he? We have to know him.

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Everyone sees someone different. That's what we show.

turns.speaker: WELLES
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: MANK
turns.text: Like a jewel. Turn it in the light and a different facet is illuminated.
